repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - On-Farm and Command Water
            Management and Irrigation Systems Rehabilitation Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
This report evaluates the On-Farm and
            Command Water Management and Irrigation Systems
            Rehabilitation Projects for Pakistan. The four projects were
            a successful part of the early implementation of the RAP
            strategy. However, they drifted away from this strategy and
            did not achieve their projected results and impact. While
            the projects had some worthwhile and widespread poverty
            alleviation impact, they also provided large transfers of
            public resources to some of the rural elite. The
            institutional outcomes of the projects were not up to
            expectations. While the sustainability of the improvements
            made to watercourses under the projects is not in doubt, the
            method of financing adopted, with its heavy reliance on
            external aid and subsidies, is not sustainable. Even so, the
            four projects were generally successful in achieving their
            main physical objectives but the greater institutional and
            social problems affecting system performance remain and may
            have increased. Two major lessons can be learned from these
            projects. First, there is a need for disaggregated
            investment packages which are tailored closely to the
            specific physical, social, and economic characteristics of
            the very different areas within the system instead of broad
            scale national projects. Lastly, there is a need for an
            improved and independent analytical base on water sector
            issues, routinely maintained in current status rather than
            being periodically updated.

repnme.cdata!: Pakistan - Second On-Farm Water Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second On-Farm Water
            Management Project for Pakistan was satisfactory. The
            project achieved its primary objects, sustainability is
            uncertain at this time, and the performance of the Bank was
            satisfactory while the Borrower's was less than
            satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, amendment of the DCA to open four provincial
            Special Accounts in the early stage of the project
            facilitated the flow of funds and expedited implementation.
            Second, application of more rigid criteria for both
            selection of watercourses to be renovated and sections to be
            lined is needed in order to avoid renovation. Third, greater
            attention should be paid to WUAs to ensure that they can
            function as intended. Fourth, use of expatriate consultants
            should be limited to specializations for which expertise is
            not readily available locally. Fifth, greater attention must
            be paid to establishing an effective M & E system.
            Finally, the Borrower should proceed with caution in
            implementing the third OFWM project and not underestimate
            the experience gained from the current project.

repnme.cdata!: Pakistan - Second On-Farm Water Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second On-Farm Water Management
            Project will consolidate the gains and address the
            weaknesses of the first On-Farm Water Management (OFWM)
            Project and similar components under other projects.
            Project objectives will be to:  a) reduce irrigation water
            losses at the farm level; b) increase agricultural
            production through more efficient use of water; and c)
            increase farmer participation in Water Users Associations in
            order to improve management of water and non-water farm
            inputs and ensure adequate maintenance of civil works.  It
            will also aim to; d) improve the capability of the
            provincial governments to plan and execute expanding OFWM
            programs; and e) strengthen the water management expertise
            of the provincial Agricultural Extension Services as well as
            their coordination and cooperation with the OFWM
            Directorates.  The three-year project will include:  a)
            equipment, materials, and skilled labor for renovation of
            about 2500 watercourses, precision land levelling,
            demonstration plots, construction of water tanks, and
            limited office space and staff housing.  It will, moreover,
            provide; b) technical assistance; c) training; and d)
            supervision and administration.
